climbs.name: Unknown Splitter Chimney AKA Blast Off
climbs.fa: not me. It probably predates "The Same Reality"

content.description:
This climbs a gorgeous, eye catching chimney. The crux is at the very bottom, and there is another at the very top.

"Blast Off" is just what I've been calling it. If anyone knows the actual name and FA info, let me know!
content.location:
It is to the right of the cave for "

The Same Reality

."

content.description:
Climb the arete to the right of "

Dreams of Gold

". The crux is up high on this one. This would be better if the start wasn't so dabby.
content.protection: 3-5 pads and a spotter. The landing is mildly built up, please do not build it up more. Falling near the top can suck but is safe with proper padding and spotters.
content.location:
It is directly to the right of "

Dreams of Gold

."

content.description:
Dreams of Gold is another great and wildly overhanging line at the Aircraft Carrier Boulders. Start sitting on some hand jams, then move up into a powerful sequence of positive (but sharp!) fingerlocks, eventually gaining some good hands again for a while. Top out by moving right onto the arete, and finish on a jug rail/easy chimney, which is another 15 feet or so to the top. The fall from the topout could potentially be dangerous, but it's all there, and you can easily inspect the holds before committing.

People with smaller hands might be able to get handjams at the beginning.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. A fall off the topout isn't recommended. Tape your fingers and hands, this boulder bites.
content.location:
This boulder is on private propery, please respect the landowners so we can continue to have access to this great area.

On the west side of the western Aircraft Carrier Boulder, it's in a massive cave. The best way to get to it is to go above the eastern Aircraft Carrier Boulder, traverse towards the west, and then drop down into the massive cave. GPS coordinates are: 39.4158225, -105. 2681033.

content.description: A very powerful V5ish fingers boulder problem with some face holds leads into a beautiful section of 5.11 enduro thin hands to hands. The whole route is about 50+ degrees overhung. The beginning is quite sharp. Tape those digits. The route would be world-class good if it weren't for the giant boulder you step off to finish. Even then, I think it is a classic for the Spires area.
content.protection: Cams 0.3 to #2.... A small bouldering pad for the beginning is very very nice to have but not necessary.
content.location: There is a cave entrance on the North side of the boulder. Squeeze through this tunnel and look right when it opens up. The crack is quite obvious.

content.description:
This is a mega classic crack boulder. Sit start on fist jams, and eventually invert into the offwidth, then pivot around the lip (spicy!), and climb an easy, lower angle offwidth (casual 5.5, but a definite no-fall zone) to the top. There are some tricky subtleties to this crack boulder where you can't just fire it, it will make you think. This a worthy tick for any climber and probably one of the best boulder problems I know of in the South Platte, and it is one of the most scenic and aesthetic boulder problems that I've ever seen. Even if you aren't an offwidth climber, you should get on this!!!

People with larger fists can possibly fist jam the entire way and make the climb a few number grades easier (maybe 5.11+ for the meaty bois). People with fists that are almost big enough, well.... It's gonna be rough (will feel stout). Like many crack climbs, the grade on this one is very size-dependent.
content.protection:
At least 2 pads, a fall from the crux at the lip will be scary but mostly safe with spotters. It is a tiny bit highball for an offwidth boulder, but not R-rated. The landing is as flat as it gets.

You could also lead it or toprope it.
content.location:
Above and to the right of the topout for "

The Same Reality

," this is the short but totally splitter OW roof. Find the aforementioned route, and look up through the 2 boulders. There is a bit of low 5th Class climbing to get to it. EDIT: as of 1/2/2020 there is a rope ladder, no longer requiring 5th class climbing and additional shenanigans to get to the boulder.
